title: Depression-Associated Musculoskeletal Pain in a Middle-Aged Office Worker
clinical_history: Mr. John Harris is a 48-year-old IT analyst with a 20-year office career, presenting with a 4-month history of persistent, non-specific deep muscular aches primarily in the neck, upper trapezius, and interscapular region, alongside generalized fatigue and low mood. He reports difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep, decreased work performance, and diminished interest in hobbies. He describes a persistent sense of physical heaviness and tension, especially on waking and after long periods of desk work. Emotional stressors began after an organizational restructuring led to increased job insecurity, and his fatherâ€™s recent diagnosis with dementia further contributed to his current state.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral upper trapezius and cervical paraspinals (constant dull ache)
lumbar paraspinal, intermittent aching and burning after prolonged sitting

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged sitting at a computer, high-stress work meetings, poor sleep, reduced activity, and ruminative thoughts late in the evening.
picture: [illustration of tension and pain distribution in neck, upper back, and lumbar region]
easing_factors: Short walks, heat packs, mindfulness breathing, supportive conversations with spouse, listening to calming music.
past_history: Three years ago, he experienced a brief depressive episode following a divorce, which improved without medication. No significant musculoskeletal injuries or surgeries reported.
medical_history: No chronic physical illnesses. Mild hypertension, managed with lifestyle changes.
medications: Recently started on Sertraline 50mg once daily (prescribed by GP for depression, 3 weeks ago). Occasional paracetamol for pain relief.
personal_history: Lives with his new partner, has one teenage daughter from previous marriage. Non-smoker, moderate alcohol consumption, sedentary lifestyle. No regular exercise routine. Expresses social withdrawal in recent months, less engagement in community or leisure activities.
imaging: No imaging performed to date; clinical examination revealed no neurological deficits or objective joint restriction.
